The electrocatalytic reduction of NO (NORR) and selective catalytic reduction of NO by CO (CO-SCR) are the two most attractive approaches for selective conversion of NO. Herein, a bifunctional metal-free catalyst 2-Pmmn borophene is reported that is effective for both NORR and CO-SCR. NO can form NH3 and N2 through NORR and CO-SCR respectively. The results show that NO chemically adsorbed on the surface of borophene through the NO terminal can be electrocatalytically reduced to NH3. The optimal reaction path for NO to generate NH3 is through the protonation process of *NHO instead of *NOH. The rate-determining step is the hydrogenation of *NH2O to *NH2OH, and the free energy increases by 0.41 eV. At the same time, NO can also react with CO on the surface of borophene to form N2 and CO2. First, NO can form chemically adsorbed ONNO intermediate through NN coupling, then ONNO can be denitrified to form N2 and residual oxygen, and finally residual oxygen and CO can generate CO2 through the LH mechanism. The rate-determining step of the reaction is the NN coupling process of NO, and activation energy barrier is 1.27 eV. The present work provides theoretical insights for the effective conversion of NO. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords 2-Pmmn borophene NORR Co-SCR Reaction mechanism Density functional theory 1 Introduction Nitric oxide (NO) is the main component of nitrogen oxides (NOx) and is a toxic pollutant emitted from vehicle exhaust and industrial production [1,2]. NO emissions can lead to various environmental issues, such as ozone depletion, acid rain, smoke, photochemical smoke, etc. [3–6] At the same time, N plays an important role in industry, agriculture, and physiology, so efficiently converting harmful NO into useful value-added products is an important research goal at this stage [7,8]. To data, there are two main pathways for the effective conversion of NO: electrocatalytic reduction of NO (NORR) and selective catalytic reduction of NO by CO (CO-SCR). NORR is not only green and efficient, but also capable of synthesizing ammonia at room temperature, which has attracted widespread attention from researchers in recent years [9–13]. Experimental and theoretical evidence have confirmed the application of many catalysts in NORR, such as metal catalysts [7,14–16], single atom catalysts [17–20], and 2D metal compounds catalysts [21–24], etc. CO-SCR is to use CO as a selective reducing agent for NO, which can produce environmentally friendly N2 and CO2 (2NO + 2CO = N2 + 2CO2) [25–27]. There are two possible reaction mechanisms for this method. One is that NO first generates ONNO intermediate through NN coupling, then ONNO is denitrified to generate N2 and residual oxygen, and finally CO and residual oxygen generate CO2 (2NO + 2CO → N2O2 + 2CO → N2 + 2O + 2CO → N2 + 2CO2) [28,29]. The other is that NO first reacts with CO to generate CO2 and residual nitrogen, and then the residual nitrogen NN couples to generate N2 (2NO + 2CO → 2N + 2CO2 → N2 + 2CO2) [30,31]. Both mechanisms have been found to be effective in previous studies. Although NORR and CO-SCR have been reported many times, most of their catalysts are metal catalysts, and the use of metal-free catalysts is very rare. Recently, many two-dimensional metal-free materials such as silicene [32,33], germanene [34], phosphorene [35], arsenene [36], and tellurene [37] have been used in many chemical reactions, attracting widespread attention. On this basis, researchers synthesized borophene composed of a single layer of boron atoms using a silver substrate under ultra-high vacuum conditions [38,39]. Research has found that borophene has a highly anisotropic crystal structure, with its band structure exhibiting gold properties, and it has been found that there is ultrafast electron transfer on its surface. In addition, experimental research and theoretical work have shown that borophene has broad prospects in catalytic applications, such as hydrogen evolution [40], oxygen reduction [41], oxygen evolution [42], and CO2 electroreduction reactions [43]. Huang et al. studied the adsorption of gas molecules such as NH3, NO, NO2, and CO on the surface of borophene using density functional theory [44]. The results showed that borophene has good adsorption sites and stable adsorption configurations for target molecules. Shen et al. investigated the effect of Cu modified borophene on the CO2 conversion mechanism, and the results showed that borophene can effectively catalyze the CO2 reaction with high catalytic activity and selectivity [40]. These studies indicate that borophene is a very good non-metallic catalyst. In this work, the reaction mechanism of NO catalytic conversion via NORR and CO-SCR on the surface of 2-Pmmn borophene catalyst was systematically studied through density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Firstly, the stability of 2-Pmmn borophene catalyst was studied, followed by the exploration of the chemical adsorption configurations of NO and ONNO on the surface of borophene. Finally, on the surface of borophene, the reaction mechanism of electrocatalytic reduction of NO to NH3 and the CO-SCR catalytic mechanism of NO to generate N2 through NN coupling were discussed. The results show that 2-Pmmn borophene as a metal-free catalysis is beneficial for the conversion of NO into other high value-added compounds through NORR and CO-SCR. 2 Calculation method All spin polarized DFT calculations were performed with the DS-PAW [45]. The exchange correlation function was handled using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) formulated by the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [46,47]. The plane-wave basis set energy cutoff was set to 400 eV, and the Brillouin zone integrations were done using a 3 × 3 × 1 k-point mesh. The electronic self-consistency criterion was set to 10–4 eV and a force convergence tolerance of 0.02 eV/Å. To account for van der Waals (vdW) interaction, we used Grimme's DFT-D3 method [48]. A 15 Å vacuum layer was added in the direction perpendicular to the interface to avoid the interaction with their own images. Ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulation were conducted using the canonical NVE ensemble, temperature control using Andersen thermostat [49,50]. Simulation is performed for 10 ps with a time step of 1 fs at 1000 K. To investigate the minimum energy path, the climbing-image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method was employed to find approximate transition states (TS), and a quasi-Newton algorithm was used to optimize the likely TS until the force acting on the atom was less than 0.02 eV/Å, and finally the nature of TS was verified by only one imaginary frequency existing in vibrational normal mode. The energy barrier (ΔEa) of each reaction step is expressed by the energy difference between the TS and the initial state (IS). The adsorption energy ΔEads between the adsorbate and the substrate is defined as: Δ E ads = E total − E substrate − E adsorbate Etotal is the energy of the adsorbate when it is adsorbed on the substrate surface, Esubstrate is the energy of the pure substrate, and Eadsorbate is the energy of the adsorbate. Based on the hydrogen electrode calculation model proposed by Nørskov et al. [51], we calculated the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) for each reaction step: Δ G = Δ E + Δ E ZPE − T Δ S There, Δ E , Δ E ZPE , Δ S were energy change, zero point energy (ZPE) change and entropy change of the reaction, respectively. The zero-point vibrational energy and entropy correction values ​​of adsorbed molecular intermediates and gaseous molecules in the reaction are shown in Table S1. On the borophene surface, the Gibbs free energy decreases by 1.43 eV from gaseous NO to chemisorbed *NO, which indicates that the adsorption of NO on the borophene surface is supported by thermodynamics. Subsequently, there are two main paths for the electroreduction of NO to NH3, as shown in the red and blue lines in Fig. 5. For the initial protonation process of *NO, N atom hydrogenation and O atom hydrogenation of *NO generate *NHO and *NOH intermediates respectively, and their free energies decrease by 0.72 eV and increase by 0.80 eV respectively. NO is more likely to form *NHO than *NOH because the decrease in free energy is more conducive to the reaction. Therefore, the protonation path of *NHO is first studied, as shown in the Fig. 5. In the second step, protons attack N atom of *NHO intermediate, and the free energy of forming *NH2O intermediate increases by 0.17 eV. It is worth noting that in the third step of proton-electron transfer, protons attack the N atom in *NH2O to form NH3 and *O intermediate, and the free energy drops by 1.52 eV, which is thermodynamically advantageous. In the fourth step, the free energy of the proton attacking *O to form the *OH intermediate is reduced by 0.62 eV. Next, the proton attacks *OH intermediate to form *H2O intermediate, which increases the free energy by 1.12 eV, which is the thermodynamic rate-limiting step of the whole process. This is extremely thermodynamically unfavorable, indicating that the generation of NH3 through this path is extremely difficult to occur, as shown in the pink path in Fig. 5. Finally, NH3 molecules desorb from the borophene surface. The N atom in NO interacts with the B atom on the surface of borophene in a covalent bond, the bond length is 1.47 Å, the bond length between O and B atom is 1.46 Å. At this time, the bond length of NO is 1.36 Å, the adsorption mode is consistent with the adsorption of single NO. The distance between two NO molecules is 3.64 Å. The subsequent direct N–N coupling via TS1 forms chemisorbed *N2O2 with an activation barrier of 1.27 eV. The chemical adsorption of *N2O2 is the adsorption configuration in Fig. 6a. In TS1, the distance between N atoms of two NO molecules is shortened to 1.30 Å, while the distance between N and B atoms is elongated to 2.06 and 2.13 Å, the distance between O and B atoms is shortened to 1.45 Å, and the bond length of NO is shortened to 1.43 Å. In *N2O2, the bond length between N and N is shortened to 1.22 Å, the bond length of NO is elongated to 1.45 Å, the distance between N and B atoms is changed from 2.06 Å to 3.37 Å, the distance between O and B atoms is shortened to 1.42 Å. Interestingly, *ONNO can simultaneously break two N–O bonds via TS2 to form N2 and two *O with an activation barrier of only 0.18 eV. In TS2, the bond length of two NO bonds is elongated to 1.64 Å, while the distance between two N atoms is shortened to 1.18 Å, and the distance between O and B atoms on the surface of borophene is also shortened to 1.39 Å. For N2+2O*, the *O-B bond length is shortened from 1.39 in TS2 to 1.27 Å, while the NO* bond length is increased from 1.64 to 3.33 Å, the NO bond is completely broken, the NN bond length is shortened to 1.10 Å, and N2 is very easy desorbed from borophene surface. This process has a strong exotherm of 2.69 eV, indicating that borophene can efficiently catalyze the direct N–N coupling reduction of NO to N2. When N2 desorbs from the surface of borophene, the remaining two O atoms will be strongly adsorbed on the surface of borophene. As the reaction continues, accumulated O atoms will cover the entire borophene surface, causing O poisoning and deactivation of the borophene catalyst. Therefore, the elimination of O atoms on the surface of borophene must be considered. Fig. 9b illustrates two different elimination mechanisms. First, two O atoms are adsorbed on the surface of borophene. The bond length of the O-B bond formed is 1.27 Å. The distance between the two O atoms is 3.43 Å. Subsequently, two O atoms are bonded to each other on the surface of borophene to generate O2, but this process requires a high activation energy barrier of 2.32 eV. In TS1, the distance between two O atoms is shortened to 1.75 Å, and the bond length of the O-B bond is lengthened from the original 1.27 Å to 1.38 Å. When O2 forms and adsorbs on the surface of borophene, the distance between two O atoms becomes 1.51 Å and the bond length of the O-B bond is elongated to 1.43 Å. Since this process needs to overcome the activation energy of 2.31 eV and the endothermic energy of 2.13 eV, it indicates that the surface of borophene is not conducive to the formation of OO bonds. The second is to use a reducing agent to react with the adsorbed O atoms to remove the O atoms from the surface of borophene to restore the reducing ability of the borophene catalyst. Since CO is the most common toxic gas and one of the popular gases in the "carbon cycle" in recent years, CO can be used to react with O atoms to generate CO2 to remove O atoms adsorbed on the surface. First, CO molecule and O atom are co-adsorbed on the surface of borophene, and this reaction follows the L-H mechanism. CO molecule are adsorbed on the surface of borophene through the C terminal. The bond length of the C-B bond is 1.50 Å, the bond length of the CO molecule is 1.17 Å, and the bond length of the O-B bond formed between the O atom and the surface of borophene is 1.27 Å. Subsequently, a reaction occurs between the adsorbed CO and O atoms. By overcoming a small activation energy barrier, which is only 0.02 eV, the adsorbed O atoms are successfully converted into CO2 on the borophene surface. In TS2, the bond length of the CO molecule remains unchanged at 1.17 Å, the distance between *CO and *O is shortened from 2.69 Å to 2.30 Å, and the distance between CO and the borophene surface is lengthened to 1.53 Å. At the same time, the distance between *O atoms and the surface of borophene is also stretched to 1.29 Å. When *CO2 is adsorbed on the surface of borophene, the bond length between C and O atoms shortens from 2.30 Å to 1.40 Å, indicating the formation of CO bond. Another CO bond is stretched to 1.21 Å, the bond length between the O atom and borophene is stretched from 1.29 to 1.42 Å, and the bond length of the C-B bond increased by 0.09 Å. Since the activation energy barrier of this process is very low and this process is a strongly exothermic process (0.79 eV), this result indicates that the oxidation of CO to CO2 is favorable on the surface of borophene. As shown in Fig. 9, NO can be selectively reduced to N2 through CO as a reducing agent. The reaction pathway is 2*NO + 2*CO → *N2O2 + 2*CO → N2 + 2*O + 2*CO → N2 + 2*CO2. The rate determining step in the entire process is NN coupling of *NO to form *N2O2, with an activation energy of 1.27 eV. The results indicate that it is feasible to use borophene as a catalyst to catalyze the joint reaction of NO and CO to form N2 and CO2. 4 Conclusion In this work, DFT is used to systematically study the catalytic mechanism of NO conversion to NH3 and N2 on borophene. First, when NO is adsorbed on the surface of borophene through the NO terminal, the adsorption energy is maximum, which is −2.05 eV. When *N2O2 is co-adsorbed on borophene through two O-terminals, the adsorption energy is maximum, which is −4.43 eV, which is significantly higher than the adsorption energy of NO. Further electronic structure analysis found that NO and N2O2 form strong covalent bonds with borophene, indicating that NO is activated by borophene. Then the reaction mechanism of NO reduction to NH3 is explored. By comparing the free energy changes, the initial protonation process of *NO is more inclined to generate *NHO than *NOH. The optimal reaction path for NO to generate NH3 is also through the protonation of *NHO. The optimal reaction path is *NO → *NHO → *NH2O → *NH2OH → *NH2 → *NH3. The rate-determining step is the hydrogenation of *NH2O to *NH2OH, and the free energy increases by 0.41 eV, indicating that borophene is beneficial to the electrocatalytic reduction of NO to NH3. Finally, the reaction mechanism of NO reduction to N2 through direct NN coupling is studied. Research has found that, similar to the surface NO dimerization mechanism of traditional metal catalysts, on the surface of borophene, two chemically adsorbed NO molecules overcome the activation energy barrier of 1.27 eV to form O-terminal adsorbed *ONN*O intermediate. Subsequently, *ONN*O breaks two NO bonds to form N2 and two *O, with a lower activation energy barrier of only 0.18 eV. This process has a strong exothermic energy of 2.67 eV, indicating that the borophene is conducive to reducing NO to N2. The two *O and *CO adsorbed on the surface of borophene are successfully converted into CO2 through the L-H mechanism, with a low activation energy barrier of only 0.02 eV. The results indicate that borophene is advantageous as metal-free catalyst for electrocatalytic reduction of NO to NH3 and thermal catalytic reduction of NO to N2. This study expands the application prospects of borophene as metal-free catalyst and provides new theoretical insights for the effective conversion of NO. coredata.dc:description: The electrocatalytic reduction of NO (NORR) and selective catalytic reduction of NO by CO (CO-SCR) are the two most attractive approaches for selective conversion of NO. Herein, a bifunctional metal-free catalyst 2-Pmmn borophene is reported that is effective for both NORR and CO-SCR. NO can form NH3 and N2 through NORR and CO-SCR respectively. The results show that NO chemically adsorbed on the surface of borophene through the NO terminal can be electrocatalytically reduced to NH3. The optimal reaction path for NO to generate NH3 is through the protonation process of *NHO instead of *NOH. The rate-determining step is the hydrogenation of *NH2O to *NH2OH, and the free energy increases by 0.41 eV. At the same time, NO can also react with CO on the surface of borophene to form N2 and CO2. First, NO can form chemically adsorbed ONNO intermediate through NN coupling, then ONNO can be denitrified to form N2 and residual oxygen, and finally residual oxygen and CO can generate CO2 through the LH mechanism. The rate-determining step of the reaction is the NN coupling process of NO, and activation energy barrier is 1.27 eV. The present work provides theoretical insights for the effective conversion of NO.
